trans-unit.source: Provides an empty control that can be used to create other controls.
By extending <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ContainerControl>, UserControl inherits all the standard positioning and mnemonic-handling code that is necessary in a user control.
The UserControl gives you the ability to create controls that can be used in multiple places within an application or organization.
You can include all the code needed for validation of common data you ask the user to input; some examples of this are e-mail addresses (see Example section), telephone numbers, and postal codes.

Another efficient use of the user control is to simply preload a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ComboBox> or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListBox> with static items you commonly use in almost every application; some examples of this are countries/regions, cities, states, and office locations.
For more information about authoring custom controls, see [Developing Custom Windows Forms Controls with the .NET Framework](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
> [!NOTE] > You might consider creating a namespace that contains several classes of user controls and compiling it into one DLL.
This DLL can be referenced and distributed with the application or all applications within an organization.
This gives you the ability to reference the user control in many applications and save time laying out and coding the contained elements of the user control.
A user control also gives you consistency within or across applications; for example, all address information input blocks will all have the same appearance and behavior.
Consistency gives your application a more polished and professional appearance.

> > You can host Windows Forms UserControl derived classes inside of a form, on another UserControl, inside of Internet Explorer on a Web page, or inside a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.WebBrowser> control hosted on a form.
> [!NOTE] > When hosting a UserControl inside of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.WebBrowser> control, you cannot turn off Visual Styles using the `META` tag value `MSThemeCompatible`.
For more information about Visual Styles, see [Rendering Controls with Visual Styles](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
Note that for Smartphone applications, this control requires Windows Mobile Version 5.0 software for Smartphones.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.UserControl"></xref> class.
You do not typically create an instance of <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UserControl>.
To create your own user control class, inherit from the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UserControl> class.
This property is not relevant for this class.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if enabled; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Occurs when the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UserControl.AutoSize*> property changes.
To be added.
Gets or sets how the control will resize itself.
Controls that do not recognize the AutoSizeMode property will function as though AutoSizeMode was set to <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AutoSizeMode>.

All controls that recognize the AutoSizeMode property will, by default, grow to fit available space, but will not shrink below the value specified by the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Size%2A> property.
A value from the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AutoSizeMode"></xref> enumeration.
The default is <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AutoSizeMode"></xref>.
Gets or sets how the control performs validation when the user changes focus to another control.
A member of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AutoValidate"></xref> enumeration.
The default value for <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.UserControl"></xref> is <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AutoValidate"></xref>.
Occurs when the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UserControl.AutoValidate*> property changes.

If your custom control performs any of its own validation, you will need to know when a developer using your control has changed the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UserControl.AutoValidate%2A> property so that you can change your control's validation behavior accordingly.
To be added.
Gets or sets the border style of the user control.
When the BorderStyle property is set to <xref:System.Windows.Forms.BorderStyle>, the control has a sunken, three-dimensional appearance.
To display a flat, thin border, set the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.BorderStyle> property to <xref:System.Windows.Forms.BorderStyle>.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.BorderStyle"></xref> values.
The default is <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.BorderStyle"></xref>.
The assigned value is not one of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.BorderStyle"></xref> values.
Gets the required creation parameters when the control handle is created.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.CreateParams"></xref> that contains the required creation parameters when the handle to the control is created.
Gets the default size of the control.
The default <xref href="System.Drawing.Size"></xref> of the control.
Occurs before the control becomes visible for the first time.
You can use this event to perform tasks such as allocating resources used by the control.
> [!NOTE] > If the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UserControl> is part of an MDI child form, the Load event will occur each time the child form is shown.
In this case, you should put any one-time initialization code in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UserControl.%23ctor%2A> instead of a Load event handler.
> [!CAUTION] > The Load event occurs when the handle for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UserControl> is created.
In some circumstances, this can cause the Load event to occur more than one time.
For example, the Load event occurs when the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UserControl> is loaded, and again if the handle is recreated.

(One way that a handle is recreated is by calling the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.RecreateHandle%2A> method.) To account for the Load event occurring more than one time, you should put any one time initialization code in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UserControl.%23ctor%2A> constructor instead of a Load event handler.
In addition, you should not add data bindings to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UserControl> in a Load event handler.
For more information about handling events, see [Handling and Raising Events](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
To be added.
Raises the <xref uid="langword_csharp_CreateControl" name="CreateControl" href=""></xref> event.
Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate.
For more information, see [Handling and Raising Events](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
The OnCreateControl method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate.
This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.UserControl.Load"></xref> event.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UserControl.Load> event occurs after the control is created, but before the control becomes visible for the first time.
Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate.
For more information, see [Handling and Raising Events](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
The OnLoad method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate.
This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
An <xref:System.EventArgs> that contains the event data.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.MouseDown"></xref> event.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.MouseEventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.Resize"></xref> event.
An <xref:System.EventArgs> that contains the event data.
Gets or sets the text associated with this control.
The text associated with this control.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.TextChanged"></xref> event.
To be added.
Causes all of the child controls within a control that support validation to validate their data.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if all of the children validated successfully; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.

If called from the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.Validating"></xref> or <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.Validated"></xref> event handlers, this method will always return <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Causes all of the child controls within a control that support validation to validate their data.
Places restrictions on which controls have their <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.Validating"></xref> event raised.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if all of the children validated successfully; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.

If called from the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.Validating"></xref> or <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.Validated"></xref> event handlers, this method will always return <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Processes Windows messages.
The Windows <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Message"></xref> to process.
